entry.title: üí° The Architect's Blueprint: Unifying Commerce for Business Growth
entry.content:
Our primary mission is to solve the endemic problem of fragmented customer experiences. When disparate systems‚Äîsales, inventory, and marketing‚Äîoperate in silos, we lose sight of the customer, resulting in wasted budget and missed opportunities. This blueprint outlines the strategic use of the SAP technology stack to achieve true Unified Commerce, providing value not just to the business, but also clear direction for our technical teams.

1. The Foundation: Customer Identity and Trust

Business Problem: We can't personalize experiences or comply with global privacy regulations without a single, reliable customer record.

Component: SAP Customer Data Cloud (CDC)

  • Architectural Role: This is our Identity and Trust Hub. It must be the authoritative System of Record for customer identity and consent.

  • Developer Focus: CDC performs Profile Unification, aggregating data across all channels into one golden record. It manages mandatory Consent Management Platform (CMP) functions, ensuring that all data activation is compliant.

  • Integration Strategy: A crucial, high-priority Profile Sync pipeline sends unified, consented customer profiles and real-time behavioral data directly to SAP Emarsys for activation. This is the bedrock of our personalization strategy.

2. The Front Door: Experience and Transaction

Business Problem: Customers demand instant, seamless experiences across all touchpoints with flexible, reliable payment options.

Component: SAP Commerce Cloud

  • Architectural Role: The API-First Front Office. It's responsible for the user experience, product catalog, and pricing. The built-in AI features enable natural language shopping queries, improving conversion rates.

  • Payment Strategy (OPF): We mandate the use of the Open Payment Framework (OPF).

    • The Value: The OPF serves as a standardized adapter layer, abstracting sensitive payment logic away from the core. This allows our teams to integrate seamlessly with various Third-Party Payment Providers (PSPs) for flexible payment options, while minimizing PCI compliance scope on the Commerce platform itself.

3. The Digital Core and Integration Strategy

Business Problem: The customer experience fails if the back office is not reliable (e.g., incorrect inventory). We need resilient, real-time connectivity between sales and fulfillment.

Core Components: SAP S/4HANA & SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)

  • SAP S/4HANA (The Digital Core): This is the transactional back-end, handling Order Fulfillment, Logistics, and Inventory. Its real-time architecture is vital for providing accurate inventory checks to Commerce.

  • SAP BTP Integration Suite: This is the Architectural Glue and Integration Layer.

    • Developer Focus: All cross-system data exchange is managed here using iFlows. This enforces the Clean Core Principle‚Äîwe do not modify core S/4HANA code for integration.

    • Key Integration: The high-volume Order Sync (Commerce to S/4HANA) is orchestrated through the Integration Suite, ensuring reliable, guaranteed delivery and a unified order history.

4. The Intelligence Layer: Activation and Personalization

Business Problem: Marketing spend must be targeted, relevant, and based on the most accurate customer profile to maximize Customer Lifetime Value (CLV).

Component: SAP Emarsys Marketing & Campaign Management

  • Architectural Role: The Unified Activation Platform. It consolidates all campaign planning, email execution, and personalization into a single system.

  • Developer/Architect Focus: Emarsys receives the high-fidelity, consented profiles from CDC. It serves as the orchestration engine for multi-wave, AI-powered campaigns, utilizing real-time triggers based on customer behavior.

üéØ Conclusion: Strategic Mandates for Technical Teams

This blueprint provides the stability and scalability required for business growth. For the developer and architect community, the mandate is clear:

  1. Enforce the Clean Core: All integrations must run through the SAP BTP Integration Suite.

  2. Profile Consistency: Ensure all systems read and write customer identity and consent data via SAP CDC.

  3. Future-Proof Payments: Utilize the OPF in Commerce to ensure a flexible, compliant payment architecture.

Following this structure ensures we deliver not just a functional solution, but a scalable, maintainable enterprise architecture.

entry.title: Create a CAP Application with SAP HANA Cloud from Scratch and Deploy to Cloud Foundry in SAP BTP
entry.content:
Create a CAP Application with SAP HANA Cloud from Scratch and Deploy to Cloud Foundry

This guide walks you through the complete lifecycle of building a CAP (Cloud Application Programming) application, connecting it to SAP HANA Cloud, and deploying it to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry.

 

1.Create SAP BTP Trial Account

You need a trial account to access Cloud Foundry, SAP HANA Cloud, and all BAS development tools.

 

2. Subscribe to SAP Business Application Studio (BAS)

If not subscribed:

  1. Go to SAP BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Instances and Subscriptions
  2. Subscribe to Business Application Studio

 

3. Create CAP Project Skeleton (Using Template Wizard)

Open BAS and press:

Ctrl + Shift + P ‚Üí Template Wizard

 

Then follow these steps:

3.1 Select Template

  • Select: CAP Project Generator
  • Click Next

 

3.2 Provide Project Details

  • Project Name ‚Üí Any name of your choice
  • Choose Database ‚Üí SQLite (default)
  • Choose Deployment Target ‚Üí Cloud Foundry

Note:
Do not select SAP HANA Cloud here.
We first deploy the application with SQLite, then add HANA later from terminal.

 

3.3 Choose Runtime Capabilities

Select these productive services:

  • XSUAA
  • SAP BTP Connectivity Service
  • SAP BTP Destination Service
  • SAP BTP Application Router

Click Finish.

This creates the complete folder structure including:

  • /db
  • /srv
  • /app
  • mta.yaml
  • Security and deployment artifacts

 

 

4. Modify MTA Configuration

Cloud Foundry sometimes fails when resource names contain dynamic interpolation (org/space).

Removing them ensures deployment simplicity.

Open mta.yaml and remove:

-${org}-${space}

from all resource names.

 

5. Create a Sample CAP Model

5.1 Define Database Schema

Open /db/schema.cds:

 

5.2 Create Service Definition

Open /srv/service.cds:

Now, you have a simple end-to-end data + service model to validate local and cloud deployment.

 

6. Test the CAP Application Locally

 

cds w

Now, CAP runs using SQLite, allowing quick testing without any external services.

 

 

 7. Deploy the CAP Application (SQLite Mode)

  1. Right-click mta.yaml ‚Üí Build MTA Project
    • Or use: 
mbt build

        2. Login to Cloud Foundry
               Ctrl + Shift + P ‚Üí CF Login

         3. Deploy the generated .mtar

    • Right-click .mtar ‚Üí Deploy MTA Archive
    • Or use:
    • cf deploy yourfile.mtar

Your CAP app runs in Cloud Foundry with SQLite.

 

Next, we will connect it to real SAP HANA Cloud

 

8. Create SAP HANA Cloud Instance

Go to:

SAP BTP Cockpit ‚Üí Instances & Subscriptions ‚Üí Create

Choose:

  • Service: SAP HANA Cloud
  • Plan: hana
  • Environment: Cloud Foundry
  • Instance Name: hanaDB

Set the DB administrator password ‚Üí required for Data Explorer.

 

And press on Create instance.

It will take estimated 10-15min

It creates the actual HANA database where CAP HDI containers will be deployed.

 

9. Subscribe to SAP HANA Cloud Tools

Without this subscription, you cannot access the DB instance UI.

Go to:
Instances & Subscriptions ‚Üí Subscribe ‚Üí SAP HANA Cloud Tools

Assign Roles

Under Users, assign all required HANA Cloud roles.

Sign out ‚Üí Sign in again.

 

10. Open SAP HANA Data Explorer

Click the HANA instance ‚Üí Open SAP HANA Database Explorer

 

First login:

  • Username: DBADMIN (or the username shown under "Administrator")
  • Password: the one you entered during instance creation

If you forgot your DB username

Open:
SAP HANA Cloud Administration ‚Üí Overview
Your administrator username will be displayed there.

 

Now, You have direct access to schemas, HDI containers, and database objects.

 

11. Open HDI Container Section in SAP HANA Database Explorer

Inside SAP HANA Database Explorer:

  1. Click the ‚Äú+‚Äù icon
  2. Choose Cloud Foundry
  3. Log in to your CF environment

 

  1. From the list ‚Üí choose Instance Type: HDI Container

At this stage, your CAP HDI container will NOT appear yet, because we have not created it.

 

12. Add HANA Support to CAP Application

Run the following commands in BAS terminal:

cds add hana
npm i

What these commands do

  • cds add hana
    • Generates HANA-specific configuration
    • Creates HDI deployment artifacts
    • Prepares the project to run on SAP HANA instead of SQLite
  • npm i
    • Installs additional dependencies required for HANA runtime

Now, your project is ready to connect and deploy models to an HDI container.

 

13. Update package.json for HANA Deployment

 Open package.json ‚Üí under "cds.requires" add:

"db": {
  "kind": "hana"
}

This tells CAP to use SAP HANA as the primary database in production.

 

14. Bind the CAP Project to Your HANA Instance

In BAS ‚Üí Cloud Foundry view:

  1. Select your CAP app
  2. Choose Bind to Service
  3. Pick your HANA DB instance hanaDB

This automatically creates a .env file containing:

  • HDI container name
  • Credentials
  • Database URLs
  • Service keys

Why we are doing this

CAP needs this information to connect to SAP HANA for:

  • Local ‚Äúcds watch‚Äù
  • Production deployment

Your project is now fully connected to SAP HANA Cloud.

 

15. Build Your CAP Project for Production

Run:

cds build ‚Äìproduction

HANA Cloud can now deploy your database schema properly.

 

16. Deploy to SAP HANA Cloud

Run:

cds deploy --production

This:

  • Creates HDI container
  • Deploys CDS schema into HANA tables
  • Activates views, indexes, constraints

Your CAP application now uses SAP HANA Cloud as its primary DB.

 

17. Rebuild and Deploy the Entire CAP Application

Again perform:

mbt build

Then deploy:

cf deploy <yourfile>.mtar

 

Our complete application (service + database) is deployed on Cloud Foundry using HANA.

 

18. Verify Schema Deployment in SAP HANA Cloud

  1. Open SAP HANA Data Explorer
  2. Click +
  3. Select Instance Type = HDI
  4. Choose your CAP application HDI container    

 

        5. Expand Tables and Views

You can verify that:

  • Tables are created
  • Data model is deployed correctly

 

19. Running CAP Application Locally Using HANA Cloud

If you want to run locally via HANA:

  1. Ensure .env exists
  2. Rebind HDI container if needed

 

 

  1. Run:     
cds w

Successful connection check

If logs show:

Connected to SAP HANA Cloud (hanaDB) . Then your HDI container is successfully connected.

 

20. Validate Deployment Using Postman

 

This confirms:

  • Service is running
  • HANA DB is connected
  • Deployment is successful end-to-end

Conclusion

In this blog, we have completed the following activities:

  • Created a new CAP application using the BAS template wizard.

  • Performed an initial deployment using SQLite to verify application behavior.

  • Provisioned a SAP HANA Cloud instance and assigned all required role collections.

  • Enabled HANA support in the CAP project and generated HDI-related artifacts.

  • Bound the project to the HANA instance to establish secure database connectivity.

  • Built CDS artifacts for production and deployed them into the HDI container.

  • Rebuilt and deployed the full MTA application to SAP BTP Cloud Foundry using HANA as the primary database.

  • Verified successful deployment through SAP HANA Database Explorer and API testing.

entry.title: How AI Solutions Can Align with SAP‚Äôs Clean Core Principles
entry.content:
‚ÄúClean core‚Äù and ‚ÄúArtificial Intelligence‚Äù are often discussed in isolation. Clean core is positioned to reduce technical debt and keep SAP S/4HANA upgradeable, while AI is usually associated with new workloads, additional components, and non-SAP technologies such as Python.

This separation leads to a common misconception: that AI solutions, especially those implemented in Python or using external models, are incompatible with a clean core strategy.

In practice, AI and clean core are closely aligned. SAP‚Äôs own definition of an ERP clean core emphasizes standardization, modern extensibility, and the ability to leverage reliable data and AI innovations on top of a stable core. When designed correctly, AI solutions can fully comply with clean core principles and in many cases help to realize the intended benefits of the strategy.

SAP Clean Core Strategy

SAP describes an ERP clean core strategy as a set of guiding principles to keep business critical systems agile, cost-effective, and ready to adopt innovation. Key elements include:

  • Reduction of historically grown complexity and custom code in the core ERP system.
  • Standardization of processes by staying close to SAP best practices.
  • Use of modern extensibility options, particularly side-by-side extensions on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP).
  • API- first and event-driven integration, rather than direct database access.
  • Cloud readiness and continuous innovation, including the ability to exploit AI capabilities.

Clean core does not prohibit custom logic or non-ABAP technology. It defines where that logic should run (outside the S/4 core) and how it should integrate (through released, supported interfaces).

Principles Relevant for AI Solutions

For AI initiatives, the following clean core principles are particularly relevant:

  • Decoupled innovation: AI workloads should run outside the S/4HANA core, typically on SAP BTP, and consume data via published APIs or data services.
  • Use of official extensibility models: Extensions should follow the models described in SAP‚Äôs clean core and extensibility guidance, including in-app extensions, developer extensibility (ABAP Cloud), and side-by-side extensions.
  • API-first and event-driven patterns: AI components should use official APIs and events to interact with core applications, rather than relying on direct table access or modifications.
  • Governed data access: Data for AI models should be accessed through governed layers such as SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere, which preserve security, compliance and lineage.

If an AI architecture respects these principles, it is aligned with the clean core strategy, regardless of the programming language or specific AI framework used.

Clean-Core Compliant AI Architecture Patterns

Side-by-Side AI on SAP BTP

SAP‚Äôs ‚ÄúGenerative AI on SAP BTP‚Äù reference architecture explicitly positions SAP BTP as the platform for AI workloads, with S/4HANA and other SAP cloud solutions used as systems of record.

In a side-by-side pattern:

  • SAP S/4HANA
    • Hosts standard business processes and transactional data.
    • Exposes business functionality via released OData/REST APIs and events.
  • SAP BTP (AI and application layer)
    • Runs AI workloads using SAP AI Core and SAP AI Launchpad, where models and pipelines can be implemented in Python or other languages.
    • Uses SAP Generative AI Hub for LLM access, prompt orchestration, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), and agentic scenarios.
  • Integration
    • Uses SAP Integration Suite, API Management and/or Event Mesh to connect AI components with S/4HANA through supported interfaces.

 

                       

AI workloads remain in the BTP extension layer, while SAP S/4HANA stays as the clean, standard core accessed via published APIs.

This pattern adheres to clean core because all custom AI logic and orchestration stay outside the S/4HANA core, while S/4HANA is accessed only via documented integration points.

AI Enabled Data Layer with SAP HANA Cloud

SAP has started using the term ‚ÄúAI enabled clean core with SAP HANA Cloud‚Äù, referring to architectures where S/4HANA remains the core ERP and SAP HANA Cloud provides an intelligent data layer for analytics and AI-driven applications.

Key characteristics:

  • Operational data is exposed or replicated from S/4HANA to SAP HANA Cloud or SAP Datasphere in a governed way.
  • AI models (classical ML or generative) are trained and executed against this data layer.
  • AI outputs are surfaced in side-by-side applications or written back into S/4HANA via APIs and standard extension points.

The core ERP remains clean and standard. AI driven logic is implemented in the surrounding data and application layers, which aligns with SAP‚Äôs stated goal of ‚Äúincreasing the pace of innovation and leveraging business value through reliable data and AI innovations‚Äù without compromising the core.

Programming Language and Clean Core Compliance

A frequent objection is that AI solutions are implemented in Python or with non-SAP frameworks and therefore cannot be reconciled with clean core.

From SAP‚Äôs standpoint, this is not correct. The clean core strategy focuses on minimizing custom code inside the core and using side-by-side extensions on SAP BTP to build new applications and innovations.

SAP‚Äôs own extensibility guidance explicitly acknowledges BTP side-by-side extensions implemented in ABAP Cloud, Java, Node.js and other languages. AI services developed in Python and deployed on SAP AI Core or container runtimes on BTP fall into exactly the same category.

Clean core compliance therefore depends on:

  • The location of the code (outside S/4HANA vs. in-core modifications).
  • The integration pattern (released APIs and events vs. direct table access).

It does not depend on whether the AI logic is written in ABAP, Python, Java or another language.

 

                                    

AI solutions built on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud surrounding a clean SAP S/4HANA core, with integration strictly via APIs and events.

 

SAP‚Äôs clean core strategy is often misunderstood as a constraint on innovation. It provides the architectural discipline required to adopt AI at scale without compromising the stability and upgradeability of SAP S/4HANA.

By:

  • keeping AI workloads on SAP BTP and SAP HANA Cloud,
  • integrating through released APIs and events, and
  • applying SAP‚Äôs extensibility guidance consistently,

organizations can build advanced AI solutions that are fully aligned with clean core principles. The question is not whether AI is compatible with clean core, but whether AI architectures are designed to follow the same patterns that SAP itself recommends for any modern extension.

SAP AI Core SAP S/4HANA SAP HANA Cloud SAP Business Technology Platform SAP Event Mesh

entry.title: Using CAP = Custom Services for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 + ESM
entry.content:
In today‚Äôs digital landscape, businesses need flexibility to extend standard solutions with custom logic and services. SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 provides this capability through Custom Services, and the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) makes it easier to build and deploy these services on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).

This blog walks you through 9 essential steps to create and integrate custom services for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 + ESM.

High Level Process flow for designing Custom Services

Step 1 :  Prepare CAP development to your Business Need

Based on the customer business requirements, you can design, develop the CAP service model.. 

Kindly refer Supported and Unsupported functionalities for Custom Services.

Step 2: Deploy to BTP

once the BTP deployment is successful, ensure your CAP Service is working fine with your credentials and test it out with CRUD methods are functional.

Step 3 : Create a Communication System

In SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2 + ESM, create a communication system to connect with your CAP deployed service:

  • Navigate to System Settings ‚Üí Communication Systems.
  • Add a new system and provide:
    • System ID
    • Host URL (your CAP service endpoint deployed in BTP)
    • Authentication details (OAuth or Basic)

Step 4 : Create a Custom Services

You can create up to 30 custom services in total, with the following limits:

  • A maximum of 30 mashup-based custom services.
  • A maximum of 15 entity-based custom services.

Navigate to User Menu - Settings - All Settings - Extensibility - Custom Services

Step 5 : Prepare CAP File Conversion

Run the following command in (your IDE where CAP is developed) the CLI to convert it to JSON: 
cds -2 json <service.cds file path> >output.json
upload the json as shown in the UI

Step 6 : Upload a File Converted

Upload the file converted from above step and upload as shown in below screen

Step 7 : Configure Host with assigning Communication System

Link your CAP service endpoint with the communication system created earlier:

  • Go to Communication Arrangements in SAP Sales & Service Cloud.
  • Assign the communication system and specify the service URL.

Step 8 : Design the App

On the UI View screen, choose ÓÅò (Create) available on the top-right corner of the screen.

Select the required UI view pattern for your custom service 

Step 9 : Assign the Business Role to the Custom Services

Finally, ensure proper authorization:

  • Navigate to Business Roles in SAP Sales & Service Cloud.
  • Assign your custom service to the relevant role so users can access it.

Search the custom services and assign the Business Role

Finally look of Custom Services (Displayed in Menu  as Workcenter)

 

Best Practices

  • Use OAuth 2.0 for secure communication.
  • Keep CAP services modular for easy maintenance.
  • Test locally before deploying to BTP.

SAP Help Documentation for Custom Services

Supported and Unsupported CAP Services to Custom Services for SAP Sales & Service Cloud v2

entry.title: What is HANA Calculation View Modeling and is it for me?
entry.content:
SAP HANA Calculation View modeling was introduced with the launch of SAP HANA back in 2010 and has become one of the most popular and sought-after skills in SAP Analytics. If you are wondering if this topic is for you, and you would like a brief description of what is it and what can be achieved, then read on.

SAP HANA Calculation View modeling is your tool of choice for modeling analytic scenarios with SAP HANA Cloud. It allows preprocessing and preparation of your data to harvest them in analytic clients. With calculation views you implement your business logic using an intuitive graphical interface.

Graphical Calculation View Editor

 

By the close integration of calculation views into SAP HANA you leverage the full potential of the performance of SAP HANA using several pruning and many more techniques.

Some Performance Optimization Options

 

Being fully integrated into SAP HANA development tooling you benefit from enterprise ready lifecycle management.

Integrated Version Control

Similarly, you can count on enterprise ready features such as multi-language support.

Support of Multiple Languages

 

SAP is working on deepening the bidirectional integration with SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) so that calculation views seamlessly integrate into BDC modeling while at the same time opening the venue to integrate BDC data products into HANA Cloud via calculation views.

 

Reporting on calculation views is pretty flexible. You can use SQL statements, SQL based tools, or you can build on the SAP ecosystem around SAP Cloud Analytics. This gives you the free choice around analytic clients. Calculation views automatically generate metadata during their deployment so that analytic clients know how to best access, display, and analyze the data. For example, information about expected prompts or type of data and their meaning are available as metadata.

 

Documentation about Meta Data

The graphical building blocks of calculation views make it easy to extend your logic and to visualize the implemented logic to your stakeholders.

 

Imagine you are asked to provide up to date sales data every morning. Instead of handcrafting a SQL statement you create a calculation view that combines the relevant technical tables in joins. This way you neither have to hand over a SQL statement nor do you need to assume that the stakeholder understands your SQL statement. Instead you point your stakeholder to the created calculation view. By enriching the calculation view with semantically meaningful data, e.g., business partner data you ensure that the report is grounded in a meaningful context.

Calculation view modeling has developed from the on-premise SAP HANA Studio tooling via the on premise browser based SAP Web IDE for HANA to the cloud tooling SAP Business Application Studio. It is embedded into the SAP Build Code environment to make sure that you can integrate it with all the other BTP development options.

Target User

HANA calculation views are the first stop if you want to encode your technical knowledge about data and tables into an easy to consume model. You can integrate data from different sources either directly with calculation views using the remote capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud or you integrate your calculation views into SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) to leverage the ecosystem of BDC with its enhanced capabilities to enrich calculation views with additional business semantics. If you are a data expert with a familiarity to databases, calculation views are your tool of choice to leverage database performance techniques while creating semantically meaningful units of reporting. Whether your purpose is to analyse large data sets or your purpose is to provide meaningful analytic reports - calculation views are your choice: Calculation views provide an easy and flexible way to build up complex scenarios in a structured manner and keep the scenarios easily adaptable and maintainable to bring the required agility into your development process.

Got interested? Read about new innovations around calculation views by visiting the blog on new calculation view features

Visit the FAQ blog for frequently asked questions

entry.title: How to Learn and Get Certified with SAP HANA Calculation View Modeling
entry.content:
SAP HANA Cloud, and SAP HANA Platform (on-premise) is a very popular solution for data management, with its powerful in-memory technology and a data model that fits a variety of data categories, including spatial, graph, unstructured data, and many more.

Calculation Views are the recommended approach to reporting efficiently on SAP HANA data using models that you design with a graphical user interface. To get an introduction to SAP HANA Calculation Views, read Jan ZWICKEL‚Äôs blog.

So how can you become proficient in SAP HANA Calculation Views modeling?

Calculation View Modeling belongs to the role Data Engineer - SAP HANA. In addition to Calculation View Modeling, this role also involves knowledge of SAP HANA Data Provisioning using technologies such as SAP HANA Smart Data Access (SDA) and SAP HANA Smart Data Integration (SDI).

The following diagram shows the Data Engineer role responsibilities compared with the Data Analyst/Data Scientist role.

 SAP HANA Cloud or SAP HANA Platform (On-Premise)?

As you might know already, SAP HANA Cloud is the technology on which SAP invests heavily, so most of the innovation is made in the cloud version, so that is where you should start if you are a beginner so that you are learning the latest features. But we also maintain a curriculum for SAP HANA On-Premise.

Let's checkout the course offerings:

SAP HANA Cloud SAP HANA On-PremiseCourse Purpose
HC300 - Developing Data Models in SAP HANA CloudHA300 - SAP HANA ModelingCover SAP HANA Calculation Views with a comprehensive course that also covers the practical aspects of the HDI Deployment Infrastructure (accessing external data, etc.)
HAHC55 - Provisioning Data to SAP HANAHAHC55 - Provisioning Data to SAP HANADiscuss native provisioning techniques of SAP HANA (Cloud and On-Premise), and covers virtualization, data replication and data transformation

These courses offer solid, theoretical knowledge, illustrations, and are complemented by demos by an instructor (HA300 instructor-led training) or recorded demos (HA300 self-study, HC300 and HAHC55).

What if I want to practice?

Here again, we have you covered!

The HA300 course is offered as an instructor-led training where you can work through lots of exercises on a provided SAP system. The HC300 and HAHC55 courses have fully configured SAP Practice Systems available, where you can quickly spin-up your own system, or access an existing system (depending on type of course and role) where you can practice a using the similar exercises that we have in the instructor-lead class. To access SAP Practice Systems you need a subscription to the SAP learning portal : learning.sap.com).

Note:  for a course such as HC300, your system is generally accessible a couple of minutes after you enrolled.

Want to learn how to access practice systems? Just click below:

  • HC300 - Developing Data Models with SAP HANA Cloud 

Live Sessions

In addition to courses and practice systems, the SAP Learning portal offers live sessions that are useful to go keep learning, ask questions, deepen your knowledge on specific topics. These sessions are delivered by subject-matter-experts (SMEs), either from SAP Training, SAP Partners or other experts at SAP such as Product Managers.

The sessions come under five categories:

  • Get Started
  • Expert Deep Dive
  • What's New
  • Get Certified
  • Stay Certified

Some of the live sessions are available for free, some require a subscription. This is visible in the example below:

SAP HANA Cloud Live Session catalog sample on SAP Learning 

So, ready for the big jump?

When you feel prepared enough, it's time to take the certification exam.

On this topic, there is some news. SAP is moving its certification model towards practice-based exams which will replace traditional theoretical/knowledge-based exams (multi-choice questions), starting January 1st 2026. Some pilot exams are already available since the beginning of November 2025.

To conclude, we are looking forward to getting your feedback on these resources aimed at getting your level higher in the area of SAP HANA Cloud modeling. Please feel free to use this new community and connect with us and other learners. Also let us know about topics you would like to have covered in future live sessions, so that we can make our content even more suited to your needs.

Happy learning with SAP!
Alain

entry.title: SAP Utilities Roadmap 2026 Onwards
entry.content:
The utilities industry will continue to play a key role in SAP‚Äôs strategy and product development. It is therefore important for us to keep customers, partners, and the entire SAP Utilities ecosystem informed about our planned innovations.

As in previous years, we have created a matrix outlining the relevant industry topics and their corresponding innovations. This matrix represents a selection of the most important innovations and does not claim to be exhaustive.

Additional innovations may be added over time, and delivery timelines remain subject to change. Following a high-level overview of the highlights, we provide detailed information for each topic. For nearly all innovations, a link to the SAP Roadmap Explorer is included for further details.

 

  • SAP Asset Performance Management:
    • Assessments for consequence classification of industrial system functions (Details)
    • AI-automated visual asset condition monitoring (Details)
  • SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud:
    • Graphical view for setting relationships between operations of one or multiple maintenance orders (Details)
    • Joule-based AI agents to propose optimized maintenance event for an asset to minimize operational disruptions (Details)
    • Support for the new Permit to Work (PTW) solution (Details)
  • SAP Field Service Management:
    • Management of measurement points on activity level (Details)
    • Dependencies between activities (Details)
    • Tool schedule visualization (Details)
    • Linear assets on the service map (Details)
    • Selection of multiple work orders through a lasso operation (Details)
    • Timesheet management in the partner portal (Details)
  • SAP Service & Asset Manager:
    • AI Assisted execution with Joule mobile client (Details)
    • Service assignment rescheduling support for field service technicians (Details)
    • Esri map improvements with breadcrumbing and draw-to-search capabilities (Details)
    • Support for the new Permit to Work (PTW) solution (Details)
    • Service assignment rescheduling support for field service technicians (Details)
  • Business Network for Asset Collaboration:
    • Integration of digital inspection checklists to support sharing with service providers (Details)
    • Modeling, sharing, and ERP system integration of failure catalogs and codes with causes and effects (Details)

 

  • SAP S/4HANA Utilities - Overall Topics:

    • Utilities Data Products (Master Data) (Details)
    • Archiving of installations and premises and deletion of unused device information records (Details)
    • Enterprise search for utilities master data (Details)
    • Continuous Influence (Details)
  • SAP S/4HANA Utilities - Metering:
    • Graphical display of utilities interval data (Details)
    • More flexible completeness check for profile values (Details)
    • Data Products and CDS views for energy settlement master data (Details)
    • Archiving of connection objects, device locations and devices (Details)
  • SAP S/4HANA Utilities - Market Process Management:
    • Utilities Data Products (Market Communication: process document header) (Details)
    • Utilities Data Products (Market Communication: transfer document header) (Details)
  • SAP S/4HANA Utilities - Contract Accounting:
    • SAP Fiori app for displaying the FI-CA document flow (Details)
    • Dispute resolution for missing payments (Details)
    • Dispute resolution agent for incorrect credits (Details)
    • Dispute resolution agent for missing credits (Details)
    • SAP Fiori app ‚ÄúManage Contract Accounts‚Äù (Details)
    • OData v4 API for contract accounts (Details)

 

  • Customer Data Cloud:
    • Support for step-up authentication (Details)
    • Consent attributes connections ‚Äì definition and maintenance of user-consent data (Details)
    • Ability to collect consent that is provided on behalf of a third party (Details)
  •  Emarsys:
    • AI-assisted campaign translator (Details)
  • CX AI Toolkit:
    • Shopping agent: related accessories based on product relationships (general availability) (Details)
  • Commerce:
    • Integration with SAP Omnichannel Promotion Pricing to display promotion recommendations on the product details page (Details)
  • CPQ:
    • Conversational AI support for quote handling (Details)
    • Integration with SAP Subscription Billing for a smooth quote-to-cash experience (Details)
  • Sales Cloud:
    • Promotion management (sales) (Details)
    • Maintaining marketing attributes for accounts, contacts, products, and registered products (sales) (Details)
  • Service Cloud:
    • Case priority prediction (service) (Details)
    • Case routing based on skills (service) (Details)
  • Sales and Service Cloud:
    • Additional features to support attachment search and management (sales and service) (Details)
    • Navigation to Custom UIs from a Mashup (sales and service) (Details)
    • Machine translation for notes (sales and service) (Details)
    • Home page AI capability for creating KPI cards (sales and service) (Details)

 

  • Distributed Energy Resources:
    • Enabling validation checks of instances through an API (Details)
    • Analytics for Long-Running Processes (Details)
    • Lightweight process for updating active measurement concept instances (Details)
  • Green Ledger:
    • Finance Intelligence: SAP Green Ledger (Details)
    • Connecting to several tenants of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management (Details)
    • Accounting for carbon allowances (CBAM) in a carbon journal (Details)
  • Sustainability Footprint Management:
    • Retrieving carbon flows from SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and posting them as allocations (Details)
    • Connecting to several tenants of SAP Sustainability Footprint Management (Details)
    • Supplier footprint integration with data exchange standards (Details)
  •  Sustainability Control Tower:
    • Cloud ERP Intelligence & Finance Intelligence: SAP Sustainability Control Tower (Details)
    • Data product for carbon journal entry (Details)
